DDB78754A5CE4A61B63C4D11FD482972.description:
describe the application of the law of conservation of momentum in a variety of situations
involving two objects (e.g., rear-end collision, recoil, jumping from a boat, traffic accidents, two
people on skates pushing each other)

AE9C8CB880BA44AB8C140FB75753C29C.description:
compare the functioning of first and second generation air bags, and explain the need for
improving the design of air bags (e.g., first generation air bag design assumed drivers to be adult
males, not wearing seat belts; for the second generation design, these assumptions were revised
to reduce speed and force of air bag deployment)

06EFDF171169432C883BD5284F9500D9.description:
analyze data or studies comparing vehicle occupant injuries, for belted and unbelted occupants,
before and after seat belt legislation

5E582B00CDFD48E4996E16605B81DEDF.description:
illustrate, qualitatively, the application of the concept of impulse to the design of automobile
safety features (e.g., dashboards, car bumpers, restraining nets, crash barriers on highways)

65A54AB133644B3F9ADCAB6AE94628F1.description:
explain how seat belts and air bags function in terms of changing momentum and force (e.g.,
explain why one cannot brace for a collision as a means of protection; explain why babies must
be placed in special seats and not on a passenger’s lap)

B4F078744C35475E98A9D03B29725C4C.description:
Apply the principles underlying the motion of objects to explain the need for safety devices and
practices

7790ECFF32E04D06B697D391DCDE6436.description:
illustrate, quantitatively, the conservation of momentum as the following: the total momentum of
two objects before a collision is the same as after the collision when friction is minimal and the
two objects lock together

51AF40B36FD2465EA8E38F3DC6A03C32.description:
analyze the force experienced, using m∆v/∆t = F, if change in momentum (impulse) occurs over a
longer or shorter period of time (e.g., stopping an object gradually over a longer period of time
reduces the amount of a potentially damaging force, and stopping an object quickly over a
shorter period of time increases the amount of a potentially damaging force)

9299F97B0FF948BCAC147F88C9B34737.description:
define impulse as a change in momentum, and calculate impulse as the product of force and the
time interval over which it acts: m∆v = F∆t

7FE56A30864748029CA992902EB0213B.description: explain why it takes a large heavy object, such as a train, a great distance to come to a stop

0F208E4A7931427792B535D99719CCFD.description:
relate the momentum of an object as being directly proportional to its mass and speed (velocity)
(e.g., quantify the momentum of an object, using the formula: momentum [kgm/s] = mass [kg] ×
speed [m/s])

353A7519DF7149AE9B5A28EA18A31041.description:
Apply concepts of force, mass and the law of conservation of momentum to investigate
one-dimensional collisions of two objects

35E12ABA6A3440C1B0D62892655D5EBA.description:
determine the distance travelled by objects during “reaction time,” when given appropriate data
(e.g., by a car when traffic lights turn from yellow to red, by a baseball to a batter, by a puck to a
goaltender)

78FD98672C8C4EB488D1CE33F5D26AF6.description:
define distance travelled as a product of speed (velocity) and the time interval, and quantify the
distance travelled using d = vt (e.g., express distance in metres [m])

C312E74F81B245CB9D83BBA4B2828E50.description:
plot a distance versus time graph, and use the slope of the graph to determine the speed (velocity)
of an object

01FB21155ABF4C8F898F57C0738D66BC.description:
define speed (velocity) as change in position during a time interval, and quantify speed (velocity)
using v = d/t (e.g., express speed [velocity] in metres per second [m/s])

56ACA22CBB594C849EFEF2BF974D1EB9.description: Describe the change in position and speed of objects mathematically and graphically

328F50794D98447E97FA19DF9AB60DF8.description:
compare the death and injury rate in motor vehicle accidents to other causes of death and injury
among adults and teenagers

0D1BCAC1902C4C37B24D003A35F45CEF.description: identify and analyze the dangers faced by people in a motor vehicle accident

118AEFF366894387AF56194FD7F8706C.description: list and describe ways that passengers can protect themselves from injury in accidents

BBCF8E94A6694300B89742AF0C8B517B.description:
list traffic safety factors (e.g., reasons why some traffic lights stay yellow for three seconds and
others for five seconds; reasons why some traffic lights have advanced warning flashers; speed
bumps; guardrails; reflectors; rumble strips)

98F6D588474949F6A3777613480D053D.description: discuss the consequences of a shorter or longer reaction time

32E00639E6FA4F099441FF67FFACC521.description:
assess the need for staying a safe distance behind another automobile when travelling at highway
speeds (e.g., maintaining a two-second gap under normal driving conditions)

B9DEDC10072546098940E0CE3850B5C0.description:
list the factors influencing the ability to make sudden stops (e.g., degree of wakefulness, visual
acuity, state of mind, ingestion of prescription drugs and/or alcohol)

91587E6689C049CBBE9BAC4913462604.description:
Use explanatory models from their own learning in science or personal experience to distinguish
between scientific and personal opinion and to analyze the need for safety systems and regulations

E2D8838579CD4AC2BA4ED5C5C1015BB3.description:
relate the advances in genetic research to ethical and social issues (e.g., the human genome
project, genetic engineering, cloning, screening for genetic disorders)

CE85D6277A284570882BC47C3959390D.description:
assess the impact of aseptic and sterilization techniques in modern medicine on human longevity
(e.g., Joseph Lister’s sterilization of operation theatres, use of the autoclave)

5DEB06F38D6D4968BC1F701E20FB47A7.description:
assess the ongoing need for public health department guidelines and personal actions to maintain
and improve upon the health of the community (e.g., food handling and preparation in protecting
human health, quarantines, use of sewers and landfills)

22A9BB807883484F9576FFAE1CEF68E7.description:
describe, in general terms, the development of a specific immunization and a genetic therapy
(e.g., smallpox vaccine by Edward Jenner or polio vaccine by Jonas Salk, experimental genetic
therapy for cystic fibrosis)

77CFB2653C304B26956571B4674A13BD.description:
Analyze how longevity in humans has increased over time as a result of a better understanding of
pathogens and genetics, and improved sanitary conditions and personal hygiene

D70CD149FEC84F16A269F5300939B5C3.description:
investigate factors that affect gene expression (e.g., effect of tobacco, alcohol, prescription drugs
and street drugs on human embryos)

ABB6EB5CA9B74EC28E92CBE10D4A3D39.description:
describe how mutations in DNA result in specific disorders (e.g., muscular dystrophy, sickle cell
anemia, Huntington’s disease)

3491142529124862B1E4BD2C291FB34A.description:
investigate the effect of mutagens and radiation on genes and chromosomes and the implications
for inheritance of genetic disorders (e.g., polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), X-rays, other forms
of radiation)

21004005A8ED433780A61BC03204092A.description:
identify the relationships among DNA, genes and chromosomes; and identify, in general, the
structure and replication of a DNA molecule

03C352C0CE0145FB8D13E4B3DB274F0F.description:
interpret a pedigree illustrating the inheritance of autosomal single gene traits (e.g., Mendel’s
research on pea plants)

7D497DBC61394CD1B69BA9AF2C0D0510.description: identify the role of chromosomes in determining the sex of human offspring

69CEAFD3A1424A8F85B8A148FEB7FBDC.description: interpret a Punnett square to illustrate dominant and recessive monohybrid autosomal crosses

2ABCB10CE03348AEBC6A665C6A77398B.description:
describe the role of genes in inherited characteristics (e.g., hitchhiker’s thumb; earlobe
attachment; hair, skin and eye colour)

3F783048CF4F4B0EABDB252FBD754A29.description: Describe the role of genes in inherited characteristics and human health

88A9F5EEE6BD45EEA66801A7BC187160.description:
describe how the overuse and improper use of antibiotics may lead to the development of
resistance in bacteria (e.g., use of prescription antibiotics for viral infections)

34F34465CBE54015B8E03E665891BFBE.description:
explain how specific antibiotic therapies, vaccines or medications are used to treat or prevent a
disease (e.g., measles, rabies, tetanus, smallpox, tuberculosis)

A95BA0A90C2D41B79D0A5B47DA8FE9EE.description:
compare forms of immunity in the human organism, and explain how immunity is established
(e.g., natural and artificial immunization)

B164179362DC4163B6DDD8C6F5068CCC.description:
describe, in general terms, how the immune system protects the body by attacking foreign or
abnormal proteins

E11A120C9B844E9F86F7D1B2E32CD4AA.description: identify the major cellular and chemical components of the human immune system

683429C88EA443FE80B3D1A5EF23A7A4.description:
investigate and explain the role of blood components in controlling pathogens (e.g., white blood
cells and antibodies)

8D01BF98D197451E81C96E4C565084FF.description:
explain the role of the human organism’s physical defences in preventing infection by pathogens
(e.g., skin, mucus membranes, tears, saliva, digestive system)

827F8416B9FA47F395C0A226F2E7EC00.description: Describe the natural mechanisms that protect the human organism from pathogens

28DE7BEA27394826A694AD5CCF320228.description:
investigate and describe how a specific food handling or preparation process is designed to
prevent microbial contamination of the final product (e.g., freezing, pickling, salting, vacuum
packaging)

810F38EDE70746BEB6BD0CA701F1961B.description:
describe how noncommunicable diseases are transmitted and how they affect human health (e.g.,
food poisoning due to salmonella or E. coli; cholera; dysentery)

99FDBE72571848DBA24F3A5E76E21ECF.description:
describe how different communicable diseases are transmitted and how they affect human health
(e.g., cold, influenza)

5F0CA149655346AAA6CCE21224337ACF.description:
investigate and describe the conditions necessary for the growth of a specific pathogen (e.g.,
viruses, fungi, bacteria)

767CED6D99EE44099D5C55C497E8CE38.description: distinguish between communicable and noncommunicable diseases

40BD7F8E01CF40409101B7C89463F42F.description: Analyze the relationship between human health and environmental pathogens

149A3FB3055F4DFF92A8D402EB7A050E.description:
analyze the impact of public health initiatives and maintaining high standards of personal hygiene
in fostering healthier societies and individuals (e.g., provision of potable water, clean air
standards, treatment of human and animal wastes, safe handling of food)

447BECBBE08C49BBBE2B7B29C505CAD5.description:
trace, from a historical perspective, the connection between diseases and contaminated drinking
water, air pollution and personal hygiene

02135DF79ECE4EC89FD4E679C846F26C.description:
list the social and economic impact of pandemic diseases on past and present societies (e.g., Black
Death; 1918 Influenza; severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS); impact of European diseases,
such as tuberculosis, on Canada’s First Nations communities)

109036536B6446C8998B225D0038F0DF.description:
analyze the relationship between social conditions and disease (e.g., hunger and malnutrition;
sanitation and bacterial, viral, fungal diseases)

CF1DA9E1BBA74BC18A1E1CA67EAE73FB.description:
describe, in general terms, how human diseases may arise from an interaction of variables,
including poor nutrition, stress, pathogens and environmental contamination

45C706AD0A8047F58A113ACDBA7110AA.description:
Describe how human health is affected by societal and environmental factors, and describe the need
for action by society to improve human health

B3759C3AB7A0421390F78CE0168813FB.description:
describe the importance of combustion reactions to a modern industrial society, and describe the
implications of depleting fossil fuel reserves

9E0A5B4E04BC4C029D40F31350EA901B.description: assess the impact of fossil fuel based technologies on the environment

22FED375539D44DC99A3FDA6597802F5.description:
describe the sources of fossil fuels; and describe, in general terms, the extraction and refining
processes used to provide people with fossil fuels

9E4703E7CB8049C4B762375A48847EB7.description:
compare present fossil fuel consumption by industry, homes and automobiles with projected
consumption in the future

FF3D053B943046418C539E4CB05826BE.description: explain the importance of the fossil fuel industry in Alberta in meeting energy requirements

8E7A2E87456F47C0A3373B6A03CE8374.description:
Analyze and describe the impact of fossil fuel based technologies and their importance in meeting
human needs

D504D435F989450AA83DCE67CA67DB63.description: compare combustion of a fossil fuel with cellular respiration

EE80A8FC8B874A4CA5514A91AD572662.description: outline, in general terms, the formation of the following fossil fuels: oil, coal and natural gas

2D2A855C9A04415CAAC3FAE952EF03A0.description:
describe the factors that affect metabolism (e.g., age, level of fitness, time of day,
exercise/activity), and compare daily energy requirements of individuals at various stages of
growth and activity levels (e.g., energy requirements of a newborn, teenager, office worker and
labourer; energy requirements while sleeping, running)

81C481D6FA8449A1BC0E48AA93261FC6.description:
identify the sources of energy in food as carbohydrates, fats and proteins; and explain, in general
terms, why there needs to be a balance between food intake and energy output

D3672E60C90B4BE58C56E1995A2BBA17.description:
describe food as fuel for the human body in meeting its needs for normal metabolic functions,
exercise, and growth or repair of cells

26D07750DD484D909E611841B1C04FA8.description:
explain, in general, the process of respiration in which glucose and oxygen are converted to
energy, carbon dioxide and water

D5E23704D4DF469386B95DA15A421C2D.description:
list and explain the requirements of photosynthesis as carbon dioxide, water, chlorophyll in
chloroplasts and sunlight; and list and explain the products as oxygen and glucose

D277730F8A3640E9BD939F1BD760F1A6.description:
investigate and describe common chemical reactions that produce or absorb energy (e.g., light
and heat given off by the combustion of fossil fuels, cold and hot packs)

925705BB36A0467FB285F220D2BEE728.description:
Investigate and describe the energy conversions associated with change in chemical and biological
systems

13EC0AB989CC4BF492E7CEAADBDE9DF1.description:
devise a plan for making more efficient use of household energy conversion devices (e.g., doing a
full load in a dishwasher or clothes dryer, using appropriate wattage light bulbs or compact
fluorescent light bulbs)

D294FD1867D142FB8792FA260E9C7906.description:
define the rate of energy transfer as power, using E = Pt; identify the units of power as joules
(J)/second or watts (W); and identify the units of energy as joules or kilowatt hours (kWh)

04FBFEBF9CF545FA941786CDDDDFD795.description: explain why the useful output energy in machines is always less than the input energy

FCF5E9974AE647FB8905C271C26B692E.description:
describe the efficiency of an energy conversion system as a ratio of total input energy to useful
output energy, and quantify efficiency as: % efficiency = useful output energy ÷ total input
energy × 100

46C5BC34B0AC423788DDBCFE2BB3E199.description:
compare the efficiency of electrical power distribution systems by tracing the energy conversions
that occur in a variety of household devices (e.g., power tools; electric cars; microwave and
conventional ovens; fluorescent, incandescent and halogen light bulbs)

991B651AEBCF495792D86EF3E0609859.description:
describe electrical power generation in terms of converting thermal/hydro/wind/solar/nuclear
energy into electricity

87F8B90D1FF64E8DBC8F2C7DE569522B.description:
Investigate and analyze electrical energy conversion devices in terms of energy conversions, rate of
energy transfer and efficiency

2F2B441F4B3C4495B13C637B6E3A3664.description:
apply the law of conservation of energy to trace energy transformation, dissipation and
availability in physical and technological systems (e.g., swinging pendulum)

76254F1261DA46CFA0BD7F6221214F57.description:
describe an energy transformation system in terms of input, converter and output (e.g., an electric
kettle)

69B6B80C12444EA8985EDAE7B16F4A65.description:
design, construct and evaluate a simple model or device that transforms energy from one form to
another (e.g., windmill, water wheel, model vehicle powered by rubber bands/mousetraps/carbon
dioxide/electric motor)

EFAAEB522BD44CFAA7EC05CD617E4381.description:
investigate and describe evidence of energy transformations in the home and everyday contexts
(e.g., simple machines, electrical devices, chemical reactions)

959B2ABC529348E6877C5A80F73E8B50.description:
Investigate and interpret transformation and conservation of various forms of energy in physical and
technological systems

C8E4584CDD014BA4A023FCAD76D9BAD8.description: investigate and describe technologies used to reduce emissions that cause acid deposition

F8C36D9F9B5B4A609136876107306564.description:
investigate and describe greenhouse gases and air pollution resulting from combustion reactions
(e.g., carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide released when methane is burned in a household
furnace, sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide released in car exhaust)

9AEF0D42423A439187580C8EDE44E19F.description:
provide examples of how technology has addressed the problem of corrosion (e.g., protecting
with paint, oil, plastic or metal; using alloys or sacrificial metals)

E102C9D9E9AB4D1D82A5CC3760285171.description:
investigate and describe simple chemical processes occurring in everyday life (e.g., acid–base
reactions in cleaning and food processing, dyeing of hair, washing of clothes, burning of gasoline
in a car engine, swimming pool maintenance, rusting of metal)

88D946B0F73D4C21B5AEAB9870F739A3.description:
analyze and explain common acid–base neutralization reactions (e.g., neutralization of stomach
acid by antacids, use of baking soda or baking powder, use of lemon juice on fish dishes)

A8EC2E0BDCE041549C29B53DEC63E30B.description:
Analyze common technological products and processes encountered in everyday life and careers, and
analyze their potential effects on the environment

B0462AB5B8DF4A368A9468317C35290D.description: design an experiment to illustrate that mass cannot be created or destroyed in a chemical reaction1.3c

9756C060DF3040A7897F34BDEAE01C8D.description:
represent simple chemical reactions (e.g., neutralization, combustion, simple composition,
decomposition) using word and/or balanced chemical equations

909E7883B24F432A93163E1F86FC4FE1.description:
relate the concept of the atom to the conservation of mass; i.e., the number of atoms stays the
same as they are rearranged in a chemical reaction; therefore, the total mass before and after the
reaction remains the same (e.g., analyze the chemical equation 2Mg(s) + O2(g)→ 2MgO(s) to
illustrate the law of conservation of mass by counting the number of atoms of each element)

3169DFABC57D4DDB9F0F0DC054018FCC.description: Explain the law of conservation of mass when balancing chemical reactions

9A9BEA3EEE434E3183C148312B42E580.description:
identify simple composition, decomposition, combustion and neutralization reactions when given
word and/or chemical equations, products and reactants

6B0A0A016571465386D56E72BB08E454.description:
describe, using observation, the chemical properties of reactants and products in chemical
reactions (e.g., neutralization, combustion, simple composition, decomposition)

6157F19DEDEB451EA678B6D2FACF4B7F.description:
investigate and describe simple composition and decomposition reactions (e.g., tarnishing of
silver, electrolysis of water)

937FB1AE64074118987788FE402B8708.description:
define, operationally, endothermic and exothermic reactions (e.g., mixing chemicals in a “cold
pack,” burning natural gas)

CA3D99638CC144F0BBB59E515C875B4A.description:
investigate, describe and compare the changes to reactants and products in fossil fuel combustion
and rusting reactions

FDBF3068A23446E0B4A75D390D516D12.description:
investigate evidence of chemical change; i.e., change of phase, appearance, colour, odour, energy
(e.g., heat, light)

CA7FA8BD2A7E49D08FD1C44E83A73AC8.description:
infer the relationship among chemical formulas, composition and name (e.g., simple acids, bases,
salts)

6E5058EA7D294B65AF25D0577E1FF711.description:
name simple compounds from chemical formulas, and recognize the chemical names of
substances that are used every day

D75EE2B2F06C43B0BCAB1AF44F6ED375.description:
identify examples of chemical changes involved in cooking, cleaning, personal care and
gardening (e.g., acids in vinegar, citrus fruits and rhubarb react with aluminum kitchen utensils;
bases in drain cleaners react with grease; emulsifiers and softeners are ingredients in skin
creams; pesticides interfere with metabolic processes in living systems)

40ADEB267E754F6DAC96CA0DA3890324.description:
identify common materials and their uses, and describe how everyday life has changed over the
past 100 years with the development of new materials (e.g., acids, bases, alloys, plastics,
ceramics, fibres, composites)

9D7F4D7DD01C43A5A732DBA41290ECA5.description:
Describe how everyday life depends upon technological products and processes that produce useful
materials and energy

76AAD14EDF394626813D8AA399F5ACF4.description: Applications of Matter and Chemical Change
